nodes.text: A likelihood-based analysis of vector autoregressive models with unit roots can be used to define, test, and interpret cointegration relations among nonstationary economic time series
Context: Cointegration describes that nonstationary processes can have linear combinations that are stationary and is central to modeling vector autoregressions with unit roots and error correction
Method: The cointegrated vector autoregressive I(1) model is specified as Delta x_t = alpha beta' x_{t-1} + sum(Gamma_i Delta x_{t-i}) + deterministic terms + epsilon_t, with alpha and beta p by r

Claim: Under the I(1) condition (unit root at one and |alpha_perp Gamma beta_perp| != 0) the Granger Representation Theorem gives a moving average representation showing xt is I(1) with r cointegration relations beta' x_t stationary and p-r common stochastic trends
Method: Reduced rank regression (RRR) estimates alpha and beta by solving an eigenvalue problem on residual covariance matrices; maximum likelihood for the I(1) VAR reduces to RRR on residuals

Claim: Cointegration coefficients beta can be interpreted as long-run relations; a coefficient gives the long-run effect of a permanent change in one variable on another holding other variables fixed in the long run
Result: The likelihood ratio test for cointegration rank r versus p is computable from the eigenvalues lambda_i of the RRR and equals -T sum_{i=r+1}^p log(1-lambda_i)

Evidence / Asymptotic result: The LR rank test has nonstandard Dickeyâ€“Fuller type limit distributions depending on the number p-r of common trends and deterministic terms; estimators of beta are mixed Gaussian while short-run parameters are asymptotically Gaussian and independent of beta

Claim: Testing and inference on beta can be conducted via scaled Wald or likelihood ratio tests which are asymptotically chi-square under regularity and appropriate normalization despite the mixed Gaussian limit

Method / Limitation: Model diagnostics (lag length, residual autocorrelation, heteroscedasticity, parameter constancy, structural breaks, outliers) are crucial because violations (especially autocorrelation and parameter instability) can invalidate Gaussian-based asymptotic results

Application: Rational expectations restrictions (e.g., uncovered interest parity) imply testable linear restrictions on cointegration relations and short-run adjustment coefficients and can be tested within the VAR cointegration framework

Extension: The I(2) model parametrization allows modeling variables integrated of order two with cointegration among levels and differences; likelihood methods extend but require new limit distributions involving integrated Brownian motion and more complex asymptotics

Method / Practical: Deterministic terms must be parameterized carefully (constants, trends, seasonal or intervention dummies); inclusion or exclusion affects whether deterministic components cumulate and changes asymptotic distributions

Conclusion: The cointegrated VAR likelihood framework provides estimable parameterizations, rank tests, and economic interpretation of long-run relations, but requires careful diagnostics, small-sample corrections, and extensions (nonlinear cointegration, small-sample methods) for robust applied use
